paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.research_focus: Potassium balance and related changes in soil under different fertilization treatments in long-term field experiments
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study's primary focus is on understanding the long-term potassium balance in agricultural soils under various fertilization regimes and its impact on different soil potassium pools and plant uptake, across two distinct sites.

research_context.study_objectives: To evaluate the long-term potassium balance in two different soil types under various fertilization treatments, assess the changes in different soil potassium fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable), and determine the potassium recovery rates by crops.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil potassium is the central element of the research, with the study investigating its inputs, outputs, balance, changes in soil pools, and availability to crops over a 21-year period.
research_context.geographic_setting: Two long-term stationary field experiments located in the Czech Republic: Hněvčeves (50°18'46''N, 15°43'3''E, 265 m a.s.l.) and Humpolec (49°33'16''N, 15°21'2''E, 525 m a.s.l.).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Hněvčeves: Mean annual temperature 8.2 °C, mean annual precipitation 573 mm. Humpolec: Mean annual temperature 7.0 °C, mean annual precipitation 665 mm with regular distribution throughout the vegetation period. Different soil types: Hněvčeves (Haplic Luvisol, clay loam, 1.06% Corg, pH 5.9, CEC 116 mmol+/kg); Humpolec (Stagnic Cambisol, sandy loam, 1.38% Corg, pH 5.1, CEC 90 mmol+/kg).
research_context.agricultural_context: Intensive farming systems typical for the Czech Republic, involving a 3-crop rotation: potatoes, winter wheat, and spring barley. Various fertilization treatments including farmyard manure, mineral NPK, mineral N, and straw + N.
research_context.study_design: Long-term stationary field experiments conducted over 21 years (1996-2017). Six fertilization treatments were applied: Control (no fertilization), Farmyard manure (FYM 1), Half dose of farmyard manure + mineral N (FYM 1/2), Mineral nitrogen (N), Mineral NPK (NPK), and Straw of spring barley + mineral N (N + ST). All three crops in the rotation were grown each year. Soil samples were taken from plots with spring barley.
research_context.temporal_scope: The study spanned 21 years (1996-2017). Plant harvest data was collected annually. Soil samples were collected twice: in 1996 (before the experiment started) and in 2017 (after the 7th crop rotation, following plant harvest).
research_context.spatial_scope: Two distinct experimental sites (Hněvčeves and Humpolec) with different soil and climatic conditions. Soil samples were taken from four replications per treatment at each site. The study aims to represent intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

concentration_measurements.parameter: Non-exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (Boiling HNO3 - Kex)
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Range of values in plough layer (0-30 cm)

concentration_measurements.parameter: Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC)
concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Calculated from NH4OAc K and CEC
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Plough layer (0-30 cm) for Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST treatments

concentration_measurements.parameter: Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC)
concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Calculated from NH4OAc K and CEC
concentration_measurements.sample_context: Plough layer (0-30 cm) for Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST treatments

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Plough layer (0-30 cm), average for all treatments
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Decreased in all unfertilized variants over 21 years.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Plough layer (0-30 cm), average for all treatments
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Decreased in all unfertilized variants over 21 years.

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Plough layer (0-30 cm), range of values
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Significant decrease at Hněvčeves in variants without K fertilization. No significant impact at Humpolec.

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop K uptake

process_rates.process: Potassium recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops
process_rates.measurement_approach: Calculated from K input and crop K uptake

assumptions: K balance calculated as K input (fertilizers) minus K output (crop uptake).
K content in subsoil was not considered in the balance calculation.

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil samples taken at the beginning (1996) and end (2017) of the 21-year period. Plant harvest and K uptake measured annually.

long_term_trends.parameter: Non-exchangeable K content in plough layer
long_term_trends.trend_description: Significant tendency to decrease at Hněvčeves (Haplic Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization (Control, N, N+ST). No significant impact on non-exchangeable K content at Humpolec (Stagnic Cambisol).
Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST) at both sites. Highest decrease recorded with mineral N fertilization. Increased in FYM 1 treatment at Hněvčeves.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for individual changes, but overall trends are discussed.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST) at both sites. Highest decrease recorded with mineral N fertilization. Increased in FYM 1 treatment at Hněvčeves.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for individual changes, but overall trends are discussed.

long_term_trends.trend_description: Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST) at both sites. Highest decrease recorded with mineral N fertilization. Increased in FYM 1 treatment at Hněvčeves.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for individual changes, but overall trends are discussed.

explanatory_factors: Soil type (Haplic Luvisol vs. Stagnic Cambisol)
Initial soil K content and mineralogy (higher non-exchangeable K at Humpolec)
Crop yields and K uptake (higher K uptake at Humpolec despite lower bioavailable K in soil, possibly due to higher precipitation and distribution)

Higher K uptake at Humpolec (by 348 kg K/ha on average for all variants) despite lower bioavailable K in soil, possibly due to higher precipitation and its regular distribution throughout the vegetation period, facilitating K availability and uptake.

between_site_differences.parameter: Potassium recovery rate from mineral fertilizers
explanatory_factors: Differences in soil properties and climatic conditions influencing K mobility and plant uptake efficiency.

cycling_processes.description: The net change in soil potassium over 21 years, calculated as the difference between K inputs (fertilizers) and K outputs (crop uptake).
controlling_factors: Fertilization type and rate (mineral vs. organic, K content)
Crop K uptake (influenced by yield and K content in biomass)
Soil type and mineralogy (e.g., presence of 2:1 clay minerals influencing K fixation/release)
Climatic conditions (precipitation influencing K mobility and plant uptake)

cycling_processes.description: Mobilization of potassium from less available (non-exchangeable) forms, primarily from clay minerals, to more available forms (exchangeable, soil solution) to meet plant demand.
controlling_factors: Clay mineralogy (e.g., 2:1 clay minerals like mica, vermiculite)
Rhizosphere processes (e.g., H+ excretion by roots)
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from the decrease in non-exchangeable K content in unfertilized variants and the ability of crops to take up K even with negative K balances.

plant_soil_interactions.description: Absorption of potassium by crop plants from the soil, representing a major output in the K balance.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Annual uptake varies with crop type and yield. Long-term cumulative uptake over 21 years is reported.
influencing_factors: Crop type (potatoes have highest K content)

chemical_processes.characterization: Potassium can be fixed within the interlayers of 2:1 clay minerals (e.g., illite, vermiculite) making it non-exchangeable, or released from these sites when soil solution K is depleted. The study implies this process by measuring non-exchangeable K and observing its decrease under K deficit.
environmental_controls: Type and content of clay minerals (e.g., higher non-exchangeable K at Humpolec due to different parent material/mineralogy)
chemical_processes.implications: Non-exchangeable K serves as a significant reserve, especially in soils with high initial content, buffering K supply under negative K balances. The decrease in non-exchangeable K at Hněvčeves indicates its mobilization to meet crop demand.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Highly negative K balance at both sites (-1124 kg K/ha at Hněvčeves, -1663 kg K/ha at Humpolec over 21 years).
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Significant decrease in bioavailable, exchangeable, and non-exchangeable K content in the plough layer over 21 years.

mechanisms: Continuous crop uptake without K replenishment leads to depletion of soil K pools.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Positive K balance at Hněvčeves (856 kg K/ha) and slightly positive at Humpolec (48 kg K/ha) over 21 years.
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Maintained or increased bioavailable and exchangeable K content in the plough layer at Hněvčeves. Less pronounced effect at Humpolec due to higher initial K uptake.

mechanisms: FYM provides substantial K input, exceeding crop uptake, leading to K accumulation in soil.
Organic matter from FYM can improve K retention and availability.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Half dose of farmyard manure + mineral N (FYM 1/2)

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Negative K balance at both sites (-493 kg K/ha at Hněvčeves, -1332 kg K/ha at Humpolec).
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Decrease in soil K content, but less severe than unfertilized or mineral N only treatments.

mechanisms: Insufficient K input from half FYM dose to compensate for crop removal.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Most negative K balance at both sites (-1744 kg K/ha at Hněvčeves, -2376 kg K/ha at Humpolec).
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Highest decrease in bioavailable, exchangeable, and non-exchangeable K content in the plough layer.

mechanisms: N fertilization promotes crop growth and K uptake without providing K, leading to severe K depletion.
Increased K removal by higher yields exacerbates K deficit.

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Negative K balance at both sites, but less severe than N-only or control treatments (-221 kg K/ha at Hněvčeves, -288 kg K/ha at Humpolec).
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Maintained soil K levels better than N-only or control, but still showed some decrease.

mechanisms: Mineral K input partially compensates for crop removal, but the applied rate (100 kg K/ha/3 years) was often insufficient to achieve a positive balance.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Straw of spring barley + N in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (N + ST)

soil_k_effects.K_balance: Highly negative K balance at both sites (-1755 kg K/ha at Hněvčeves, -1557 kg K/ha at Humpolec).
soil_k_effects.soil_k_content: Significant decrease in soil K content, similar to control or N-only treatments.

mechanisms: Straw returns some K, but the amount is insufficient to meet crop demand, leading to K deficit.

soil_k_impacts.K_balance: Organic fertilization (FYM 1) was the only treatment to achieve a positive K balance. Mineral N fertilization led to the most negative K balance. Mineral NPK fertilization reduced K deficit but did not eliminate it.
soil_k_impacts.soil_k_pools: FYM maintained or increased soil K pools, while mineral N fertilization significantly depleted them. NPK fertilization mitigated depletion but did not prevent it entirely.

management_practices.implementation_details: FYM applied in autumn to potatoes. Mineral P and K applied to each crop in autumn. Mineral N applied in spring (potatoes, spring barley) or split dose (winter wheat).
management_practices.temporal_effects: Long-term (21 years) impacts on K balance and soil K pools.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Effects varied between sites due to differences in soil type and initial K status.

soil_k_impacts.K_uptake: Different crops have varying K uptake demands (potatoes highest). The rotation influences the overall K removal from the system.
soil_k_impacts.K_balance: The cumulative K removal by the rotation contributes significantly to the negative K balances observed in many treatments.

management_practices.implementation_details: All three crops grown annually in rotation.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Crop yields and K uptake varied between sites, influencing site-specific K balances.

soil_k_differences.K_balance_Hněvčeves: FYM 1: +856 kg K/ha; N: -1744 kg K/ha
soil_k_differences.K_balance_Humpolec: FYM 1: +48 kg K/ha; N: -2376 kg K/ha

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Statistically significant differences in K balance and soil K changes between treatments.

soil_k_differences.K_content_decrease_unfertilized: Decreased in all unfertilized variants (Control, N, N+ST). Highest decrease with mineral N fertilization.
soil_k_differences.K_content_increase_FYM1_Hněvčeves: Increased in FYM 1 treatment at Hněvčeves.

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for individual changes, but overall trends are discussed as significant.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g air-dried soil (≤ 2 mm) mixed with 30 mL of 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.002 mol/L DTPA solution, shaken for 1 hour.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g air-dried soil (≤ 2 mm) mixed with 30 mL of Mehlich 3 solution (0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA), shaken for 5 minutes.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 3.00 g air-dried soil (≤ 2 mm) mixed with 30 mL of 1 mol/L ammonium acetate (pH 7.00) solution, shaken for 2 hours, followed by centrifugation.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

analytical_methods.procedure_description: 2.5 g finely ground soil mixed with 25 mL of 1 mol/L HNO3, heated for 10 minutes after boiling, filtered, and diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia)

target_parameters: Potassium content in plant biomass (grain, straw, tubers)
analytical_methods.procedure_description: Plant samples dried at 40°C, followed by dry decomposition.
analytical_methods.instrumentation: Atomic adsorption spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia)

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples taken from plots with spring barley. Four replications per treatment at each of the two sites.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil samples collected in autumn 1996 (before experiment) and autumn 2017 (after 7th crop rotation, following plant harvest). Plant samples collected annually at harvest.
sampling_design.sample_processing: Soil samples were air-dried and sieved to ≤ 2 mm. For boiling HNO3 extraction, soil was finely ground. Plant samples were dried at 40°C.
sampling_design.storage_handling: Not explicitly detailed beyond drying and sieving.
sampling_design.representativeness: Soil samples from spring barley plots are assumed to represent the plough layer (0-30 cm) for the respective treatments and sites over the 21-year period.

method_comparisons: Strong correlation (Pearson's r = 0.989) between K content determined by Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods, with regression equations provided for both sites (Hněvčeves: y = 0.974x + 7.6145, R2 = 0.9772; Humpolec: y = 0.9505x + 5.6757, R2 = 0.9815).
uncertainty_sources: K balance calculations did not consider K content in the subsoil, which can be a significant potassium source for plants.
Continuous mobilization of non-exchangeable K is a complex process not fully captured by simple balance equations.

climate_conditions.temperature: Hněvčeves: Mean annual 8.2 °C; Humpolec: Mean annual 7.0 °C
climate_conditions.precipitation: Hněvčeves: Mean annual 573 mm; Humpolec: Mean annual 665 mm
climate_conditions.seasonality: Humpolec characterized by regular precipitation distribution throughout the vegetation period.

soil_properties.classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam (4.4% clay, 77.0% silt, 18.7% sand); Humpolec: Sandy loam (5.8% clay, 43.6% silt, 50.6% sand)
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: Developed on loess; Humpolec: Developed on loess on paragneiss (implying potential differences in clay mineral types, e.g., 2:1 types, mica, vermiculite, affecting K fixation/release).

landscape_context.topography: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.
landscape_context.drainage: Not explicitly detailed, but Stagnic Cambisol at Humpolec implies impeded drainage.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Long-term field experiments established in 1996, implying continuous agricultural use prior to and during the study.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K measurements are directly linked to crop K uptake and yield data to calculate K balances. Soil K content is correlated with different extraction methods. Soil properties (texture, pH, CEC, Corg) and climatic conditions are used to explain differences in K dynamics between sites.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Plant K content and crop yields are crucial components of the K balance calculation and are used to assess the efficiency of K recovery from different fertilizers. The study highlights how crop uptake drives K depletion in the absence of sufficient K fertilization.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The research contributes to understanding long-term nutrient cycling and sustainability in intensive agricultural systems, particularly concerning potassium management and the risk of K deficit in soils.
research_integration.comparative_context: Results are compared with findings from other long-term experiments globally (e.g., Bad Lauchstadt, Rothamsted) and within Europe regarding K content, uptake, and balance, validating the observed trends and placing them in a broader scientific context.
research_integration.literature_positioning: The study builds upon existing knowledge of potassium biogeochemistry, including the roles of exchangeable and non-exchangeable K pools, K fixation by clay minerals, and the impact of different fertilization strategies on soil K dynamics.

spatial_limitations: Soil analyses for the manuscript were based only on samples taken from plots with spring barley, which might not fully represent the entire crop rotation effect on soil K dynamics across all crops.
methodological_constraints: K balance calculations did not consider K content in the subsoil, which can be a significant potassium source for plants, potentially leading to an underestimation of K availability or an overestimation of K deficit.
The study did not explicitly quantify the rates of K release from non-exchangeable pools, but rather inferred it from changes in pool sizes.
interpretation_caveats: The continuous mobilization of non-exchangeable K is a complex process that may not be fully captured by the balance equations, especially in soils with high reserves.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All available soil potassium-related information, including quantitative measurements, methodological details, and contextual factors, has been extracted. The native research context, including specific treatments, sites, and observed trends, has been preserved. Some statistical details (e.g., p-values for all comparisons) were not explicitly provided in the source text for all findings, which limits their extraction.
